abstract.p: Letter from David R Runkel says Carolyn Curiel, in Feb 8 Op-Ed, speaks of American television's negative impact on small country of Belize; says his experience in that country showed there were also positive results from exposure to American television

block.p: In ''The Serpent in the Camera'' (Op-Ed, Feb. 8), Carolyn Curiel, the ambassador to Belize, reviews American television's negative impact on that small country.

My experience in Belize in the first half of the last decade showed that there was also a positive result: American news programs and the televising of reporting techniques of American journalists provided valuable examples to a generation of young Belizeans seeking to introduce an independent press in the country.
In ''The Serpent in the Camera'' (Op-Ed, Feb. 8), Carolyn Curiel, the ambassador to Belize, reviews American television's negative impact on that small country.

My experience in Belize in the first half of the last decade showed that there was also a positive result: American news programs and the televising of reporting techniques of American journalists provided valuable examples to a generation of young Belizeans seeking to introduce an independent press in the country.

Although the party-affiliated newspapers are still widely circulated, Belize is better off as a result of journalists -- most working in the broadcast media -- who are unafraid of asking tough questions of politicians.
In my communications classes in Belize City, my students routinely rated American television and televised movies as having a far greater impact on their country than American diplomacy.
DAVID R. RUNKEL Silver Spring, Md., Feb. 9, 2001
